conclusion: Determine the minimum turning radius r for total internal reflection in the optical fiber.
Total internal reflection occurs when light in a medium with higher refractive index hits a boundary with a lower refractive index at an angle greater than the critical angle.
The critical angle θc is given by sin(θc) = 1/N, where N is the refractive index of the optical fiber.
The optical fiber is bent into a semicircle with radius r.
Light enters perpendicularly at face A and must travel along the curved path to exit perpendicularly at face B.
For TIR to occur, the angle of incidence at the fiber's inner boundary must be greater than or equal to the critical angle.
The angle of incidence θi at the inner boundary is related to the radius of curvature r and the diameter D of the fiber.
The condition for TIR is sin(θi) ≥ sin(θc).
The angle θi can be approximated by the geometry of the semicircle: sin(θi) = D/2r.
Setting D/2r equal to the critical angle condition: D/2r = 1/N.
Solving for r gives r = ND/2.
The turning radius r of the central axis of the optical fiber should be not less than ND/2 to ensure total internal reflection.
